utterances: I don't think anything's going on with the G-man.
As a matter of fact, all of his teammates love him.
They support him and they don't find that there's a problem with him.
Actually the problem is more, to me at least, a media creation than it is in-house creation.
Plaxico Burress is known within the locker room as being one of those tardy people who's - you know, and people - some people are like that.
They're just late people.
And he is one of those people.
He's constantly late for meetings, constantly forgetting to call the offices, et cetera.
And in this case, he's estranged from his wife, his son was having a problem, he needed to get to school, et cetera, as you said.
He did what he had to do.
Yes, he forgot to call the team.
He's been fined over and over and over for this type of thing.
It's nothing new for him.
And his reaction to it actually spoke to that fact that it's really nothing new and no big deal.
It's all water under the bridge and everything's OK.
What is it, Greg Lee, about these wide receivers?
T.O., Randy Moss, Ocho Cinco?
I mean, these guys, they are like crazy?
Why is that?
Hi.
Thanks for taking my call.
Receivers, you know, they're the kind of guys who, they thrive in the spotlight.
They want the ball.
They feel like they need the ball.
It's a very extravagant position.
I love T.O., I love Ocho Cinco.
I loved the wide receiver position.
But at the same time, a lot of these receivers, yeah they do get, you know - get under the skin of some fans and even some of their teammates.
But at the same time, T.O is very passionate.
T.O.
gets out on the field, he practices hard.
He plays real hard.
He goes all out.
Ocho Cinco is the same way.

So although some of the receivers get a bad rap, but the reality is that they're really hard workers and they wouldn't be the players that they are today if they didn't put any hard work or any time to it.
So I really look at that more so - the flamboyance of the receiver position.
But it is what it is with that position.
You've got to accept it and within a case of the T.Os and the Ocho Cincos and the Plaxico Burresses, Plaxico caught a winning touch on the Super Bowl.
T.O.
constantly produces.
So I have no problem with it.
You're right.
High risk.
High reward.
All right guys, we're going to end sports bloggers this week on this topic.
It is October, which means this is the one month of the year where every major sport is going, including the big four, baseball, football, basketball even hockey for crying out loud.
Plus college football.
How many games do you guys watch a week?
How many TV sets do you have going?
I've got about 30 seconds for you, D-Will, on that.
I actually have three televisions, DirectTV, and a full package for everything.
So - and, of course, I'm sitting with a laptop as well.
So I'm watching sports all the time.
Really?
What about you, Greg?
How many TVs going on your house at the same time?
Three with TiVo and plus I have all the packages.
And when I'm not home, I can get the DirectTV NFL package on my laptop.
So when I'm away, I can watch football on my laptop.
So it's NFL.
I feel you guys.
I have one station on in my office, another station on in the family room, and another station on in the kitchen.
So when I'm going back and forth and back and forth I don't miss any of the action.
One final really, really quick note about basketball.
Elgin Baylor, the Hall of Famer let go by the Clippers, there may be some legal action.
The team has been a laughing stock for so long.
I'm going to just ask you really quickly, D-Will, in about 10 seconds.
Was this deserved do you think?
Yes.
Elgin Baylor's presided over a losing program for 20 years now.
It's about time a change was made.
That's too bad.
A great guy.
But the team, they suck.
There's just no way of putting it another way.
Greg Lee is an online sports writer for the Boston Globe.
He joined us from WBUR in Boston.
D-Will writes for the blog Sports on my Mind.
He came to us from the studios of KUT in Austin, Texas.
Now, from foreign to domestic issues.
The economy was a big topic in the recent chats between Pastor Rick Warren and Senators McCain and Obama.
One of the most challenging questions he put to the candidates, define rich.
If you're just talking about income, how about five million?
I would argue that, if you're making more than 250,000, then you're in the top three, four percent of this country.
You're doing well.
Senators McCain and Obama answered with two very different figures.
In today's economy, figuring out who is rich and who's middle class is a bit tricky.
Here to help us sort through it is Jared Bernstein.
He's a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
Thank you for joining us.
And if we could start off talking numbers, you know, we use income levels to make all sorts of assessments, but is there any way to numerically determine whether or not someone is rich?
No, there isn't.
There's just too much variation around the country's geographical variation.

Someone who has an income of 150,000 dollars and lives in a poor rural neighborhood in the South is absolutely rich, yet that income in the city of Manhattan with a kid or two going to a top university paying sticker price, I'm sure you're feeling a pinch.
What I can tell you, the number that John McCain cited, five million dollars, there's almost nobody up there.
And what about middle class?
That one seems even mushier.
Is there any way to kind of relatively gauge whether or not you can be considered middle class?
My definition of middle class would be between 35,000 and somewhere like 100,000, which is a range that's probably too broad to be meaningful to anyone.
To me, the numbers really don't help you that much here.
I think it has a lot to do with the kind of access to opportunity or the choices that you have in life that really determines whether you're rich or middle class.
And whether or not you consider yourself rich or middle class, what effects or implications does that have on a person in terms of how they spend, how they save, what job choices they make?
I think there are people lower down the income scale, say lower-middle class or poor, who have to ask themselves, can I afford to go out to eat tonight?
Can I afford this long distance call or another month of cell phone bills?
Can I afford an Internet connection?
Yet, those questions don't arise very often for people in the middle class, and they don't arise at all for rich people.
So it has a lot to do with choices.
We heard earlier how each of the presidential candidates assessed wealth.
How might their understanding affect the way that each of them would run this country?
What you heard Obama say is, if your income is above 250,000, you're doing pretty well.
His tax plan actually does raise taxes on people whose income is above 250,000.
McCain has a very different view.
Now, you heard him say five million dollars.
I think he just threw out that line, I wouldn't really attack him too much on that.
McCain is kind of following the Bush model of tax policy, where you cut taxes quite deeply at the top of the scale, not much in the middle or the bottom.
Obama's closer to the Clinton model, where you get some tax relief to the folks in the middle and the bottom, and you raise taxes at the high end.
Jared Bernstein of the Economic Policy Institute, thanks.
You're welcome.
Go ahead.
The FDA said it was investigating the deaths of 13 cats and a dog related to the recall.
Pet owners are an anxious, if affectionate, bunch to begin with, and stories on the pet food recall where the most popular search on the news page of Yahoo.com.
In just a minute, we'll talk about how you can best protect Muffy, Fluffy, or Butch.
But first, Amy Dickinson joins us from our bureau in Chicago.
Her column is syndicated by the Chicago Tribune.
Amy, always good to talk to you.
Hey, Neal.
You know, I was thinking about the whole pet thing.
These relationships are so important to people.
But sometimes, you know, we forget it until I called my own home answering machine, as I often do, today, and I said Chester(ph), who is a good boy?
You know, I - I'm as bad as anyone.
Well, if you have a pet or a pet owner who's plaguing you or if any other furs flying, give us a call, 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK, and the e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog, npr.org/blogofthenation.
And, Amy, I know you get a lot of questions for your column about pets one way or another.
A lot.
I was surprised when I first started writing this column how often I hear about pets and pet problems.
And the problems, of course, are between people, but often pets introduce - it's the proverbial triangle.
A pet will introduce what I call, like a point of tension between couples, families or very often, neighbors.
Couples?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
The old, you know, I - when I met him, I loved Muffin, his dog, that slept with him.
But now it seems, you know, Muffin is more important to him than I am.
There are a lot of pets, you know, we feel very, very strongly about the animals in our life and we do consider them as family members.
But sometimes, your human family members don't feel quite as strongly as you do.
And sometimes your neighbors can act pretty nonhuman about some of these issues.
Yes.
I get a lot of questions about - can we say, poo on the lawn?
Yes, poo, I think we can go with.
Okay.
Of course, the breaking pet news of the week is clearly the pet food recall, so I know you've brought an expert there to join us.
Steve Dale is a pet specialist.
The author of the twice-weekly syndicated newspaper column, My Pet World, as well as a radio host to several programs on pets and pet health.
He's there with you in the Chicago bureau.
And Steve Dale, thanks very much for being with us.
Hi, Neal, a pleasure to be here.
So, briefly, tell us what happened here?
We don't know yet.
And this came so much as a surprise in so many ways.
It all came from one company called Menu Foods.
And the surprise is, to those of us who cover the pet beat, to nutrition experts I know - is that this one company is responsible for manufacturing so many foods.
And what I now know, that I did not know, is the same is true of our food.
You go into a grocery store, you pick up applesauce.
Well, it turns out it might be manufactured at the same place that five or 10 other applesauce brands are.
I did not know that.
Mm-hmm.
So is this a continuing problem?
Has all the pet food been taken off the shelves?
I hope - I mean, we don't know.
I mean, I certainly hope so.
I mean, as of last week, I was hearing that people were going into a pet store with the printed out sheet from the Internet, and they were finding it.
And the person at the pet store would say what recall?
But I can't fathom that that is any longer the case.
Mm-hmm.
Amy, did you get a lot of letters about this?
Well, it's really amazing.
Just yesterday, I got an e-mail from a young girl who said that they had just euthanized her cat.
Now she claimed that it was because of this pet food situation, I have no idea.

But she was very anguished, and actually her question was really beautiful because she wanted to know how to talk about this animal and remember this animal in an appropriate way, which is something I've dealt with in my own life.
And I suggested that she do something that I've done for a beloved pet, which is to create a little shrine.

And I know it sounds goofy, but it really helps if you gather the animal's toys and the leash and you kind of put them in the bowl along with - in my case, I actually wrote, you know, the 10 things I loved about this pet, you know.
And it's a way to just kind of remember these animals.
They're so important to us.
Let's see if we can get some callers on the line.
E-mail talk@npr.org.
And we'll begin with Lucian(ph).
Lucian joins us from Kansas City.
